So you have decided that you want to do something about your body and you want to build some muscle. Your body is a very complex machine and it is important to know the proper techniques in order to get this done. The following article will help you with what you need to know.  Focus on working out your largest muscle groups. Concentrating your efforts on large muscle groups such as the back, chest and legs will help you to build muscle faster. Exercises such as squats, pull-ups, bench presses, and dips are ideal for this. These kinds of exercises are generally more intense, and will help boost your protein synthesis.When attempting to build muscle mass, it is important to ingest the right foods. If your efforts to add bulk are stagnating, it could be because you have an insufficient nutritional intake. To add bulk, you need to consume at least 4000-6000 calories each day from foods, which are calorie dense. Some examples of calorie-dense foods are pasta, nuts, eggs, bagels, trail mix and steaks. Since vegetables have low calorie-density, keep their intake to a minimum.Milk is a wonderful drink that will offer you many vitamins that are needed when you are trying to build muscle. You have heard as a kid that drinking milk will make you grow, and they have found that is also the case with adults and muscles. Enjoy 3 cups a day, and it will help you out.Prepare your body for your weight training. You must consume about twenty grams of protein thirty minutes prior to your session. This will amplify the muscle building that takes place as you lift. This is a simple as drinking a couple of glasses of cold milk before you weight train, as well as after.Carbs are a key component to building muscle. Carbohydrates fuel your body to allow it to perform the exercises that you need to do each day. If your training is extensive, you may need to increase your daily consumption of carbs to 2-3 grams for every pound you weigh.Do not overwork your body. In order to build muscle mass, your body needs a chance to recuperate. When starting out, work your upper on one day, then work your lower body the next day. Take one day off each week where you do no workouts at all. This will make the workout less of a job.A great tip for growing muscle that is often overlooked is getting an adequate amount of sleep. Your body heals itself and changes while sleeping. Therefore, if you don’t get enough of it, you aren’t allowing your body the chance to do these things. If you are working out hard, aim for at least eight hours of sleep, if not more.As you can see there are plenty of things that you can do that will help you build your muscles the right way. So whatever your motivation is for wanting to build muscles, be sure to keep the information you just read in mind. It will help you get the body you want without any injuries.

Seeking advice- Why aren’t I losing this time?This is my 3rd time hopping back on the keto horse. The first two times, I lost weight like nobody’s business- 30-35 pounds in a couple months, WITHOUT exercising. Just plain ol’ low carb, high fat, and portion control. So- I started Keto again about a month ago, this time with a full gym membership. 4-5 days a week, I workout hard. Heavy weights, and 20-30 minutes of moderate cardio. This time? After a month? 10 pounds. It was 13, but after leg day, I took a 3 day rest and apparently GAINED 3lbs. The only thing I’m doing different this time is a little extra protein (Because the tons of lifting). Oh, and this time, compared to last time, I’ve cut almost ALL diet soda (I may have 1 when we go out to eat) and alcohol consumption. Oh, and my ketostix? Always purple. People have told me I look a bit thinner, but 10 pounds? Maybe it’s because I didn’t take before pics, but I’m still very unsatisfied with the size of my whiskey gut Any ideas as to whats going on? Am I having muscle gains THAT ridiculously good that they’re keeping me at 300? Is it the post-lifting protein? Am I the world’s first pregnant dude? By Cliff WalshThere are a lot of reasons why people can’t or don’t lose weight. Metabolism is often a quite significant one. Your metabolic rate is the rate at which you burn calories in breaking down food for energy. Many people have metabolisms that are operating below peak rates. I hope to help you rev up yours by taking a handful of steps.  While genes and age impact everyone’s metabolism, a substantial amount of our metabolic rate is under our own control. These action steps are the focus of this article, which are research based and all natural ways to boost your metabolism.  Different macronutrients (protein, carbs, and fat) require different energy expenditures by the body in order to digest the food. Protein burns roughly 5x-6x more calories during digestion than a similar amount of calories of fat and about 3x more than carbohydrates. Eat your weight in protein grams and see your metabolic rate soar.  I highly recommend increasing your water intake. First, it will help your kidneys better digest your increased consumption of protein from the previous step. But it also has its own metabolic kicker of its own. Dehydration can limit proper functioning of metabolism so proper hydration is necessary. Drink an ounce of H2O for every pound you weight. Add a cup of water for every fifteen minutes of exercise you do during the day. Ice water can take your water consumption up another level as it adds the thermo effect to the aforementioned benefits. Cold water needs to be warmed up to match the temperature of the rest of your body.  Frequent, small- to medium-sized meals also boost metabolism. It’s best to target at least five meals, if not six or seven. Eat a few hundred calories every few hours rather than 800-1000 three times a day. Try to get at least 15g of protein in each meal. It helps to get into a rhythm, too. If you eat seven meals today and two tomorrow, it will mess with the thermal effect of your food. I also recommend eating breakfast within an hour of waking up and with a good amount of protein.  I also recommend eating whole foods rather than those that are processed and typically loaded with chemicals, sugar, and fat. If you choose to eat a packaged food, make sure you read the food labels to understand the nutrition content of the food and what other harmful chemicals and additives may be in your food. Something like high fructose corn syrup tricks your brain and body and doesn’t stimulate an insulin response, which can lead to overeating.  Exercise also plays a big role in increasing metabolism. I recommend weight lifting at least three times a week. Use weights that will drive you to failure at no more than twelve reps. Six to ten is an excellent range to target. Also, having more muscle means more calories burned. In terms of cardio, I recommend interval training, which flip flops between sprints and slower movements. You can get a great cardio workout in only twenty minutes instead of running five miles in an hour.  If you want your metabolism, brain, and overall body to function at its best, it is important to get a good night’s sleep. Although sleep may not impact metabolism directly, a lack of it can cause you to crave unhealthy foods and skip workouts. Get the proper rest.  I caution everyone on the use of diet pills and other quick fixes. These rarely have a positive, long-term impact. If they did, our country wouldn’t have the obesity rate it does. What you see here is my Post Work Out Meal, its a Tuna, Tomato, Lettuce, Red Onion, and home made lime and pepper yoghurt wholegrain wrap.At least here I captured it before it fell apart on me, wraps are so messy but so fulfilling. The making of the wrap is even messier! You see these pictures of people prepping food on nice wooden cutting boards and their cool knifes and vibrant colours and if you saw my bench its a mess of everything everywhere which I now gotta clean. Thats why they call it clean eating ;) Lol that was bad, I apologise, you probably got a little dumber reading that :pAnyway I just did an hour of cardio and bodyweight toning workouts. Drunk my 750ml bottle of water and decided to make this (who am i kidding i decided ages ago...but i was tossing up between chicken and tuna) Seeing as I have a lot of TAFE work to do now I thought gimme the brain power!Anyway here are the ingredientsHalf of a medium tomatoThree strips of red onionShred a chunk of tuna (tablespoon?)A handful of mixed lettuce1 Wattle Valley Wholegrain Soft Wrap Lime and Pepper Yoghurt:Half of a small limeA dollop of Chobani No Fat Greek YoghurtPepper to taste With the yoghurt just mix the flavours through and keep tasting to desired taste. With the wrap, prepare how you like, I started with the tomato then tuna then yoghurt, then lettuce, then onion and attempted to wrap it...attempted. Anyway hope you like it, it is packed with protein and carbs which you need for post workout meal and is super tasty! If you don’t like tuna try turkey or chicken. (: I’m off to clean this mess and do some work!Have the most loveliest day ever! xx

Gulp! My latest obsession... Living healthy and having fun with my grandchildren.  I am a self proclaimed foodie and there is a very short list of things I don't enjoy eating.  That is why I am overweight.  Food is my drug of choice. I have finally come upon a way to eat that satisfies my need for variety but allows me to loose weight. I have been able to control my sugar cravings with the following approach toward food.      First of all, I want you to know I have been eating mostly Paleo for the past 14 weeks.  That means I try to stay away from sugar, dairy, legumes and grains, especially  wheat.  I focus my diet on eating meat and fish and plenty of a variety of vegetables ( organic when possible) along with nuts and fresh or frozen fruit.  I do eat potatoes (red is better) but try to eat sweet potatoes when I have a choice. I cook with coconut oil and/or olive oil.  I season with garlic (powder for convenience). Sweeten my tea with stevia and  try to stay way from other artificial sweeteners .  My almost nightly dessert is frozen fruit with shredded coconut and coconut yogurt made into a soft serve ice cream using my Yonanna .  I will say, the hardest thing was letting go of bread.  I can say I'm ok now but it took several weeks of seeking out alternatives and determining there is nothing like light fluffy bread.  I made Paleo bread but it has a lot of egg and is extremely dense.  I just had to GET OVER that need and get on with it.  I have to admit I don't miss it like I used too. I think it is because I feel so good.  I find that I am becoming a food snob.  If I'm going to eat something that I consider off my guidelines, it better be worth it and good quality.  I probably eat as described above about 90% of the time.  A few years ago I had a blood test done which pointed out some food allergies which I have confirmed with practical application.  I love eggs but they don't love me,  too many will cause extreme gas and no one wants to be around me.  Same with bananas.  Small amounts will not bother me (like an egg in  a cake) but a fried egg is not a good choice. ;-).  I think eliminating these things have contributed to my digestive health.  That said, my 10% is as follows... I will occasionally eat corn, and I can't resist a corn tortilla wrapped around grilled shrimp. Living in Texas for over 30 years, I absolutely love Mexican food and cannot totally eliminate cheese or an occasional pinto bean, though I try to limit it.  I also love barbecue though I try not to smother it in sauce.  I don't eat fried food, though I will snag some of my husband's fries if he gets too many.  I love a good burger and will try to get a lettuce wrap  with avocado and all available veggies or a Gluten free bun or (in a pinch) settle for a  regular bun and eat half of it.   I use avocado instead of mayonnaise to moisten my food but if there is mayo on something I will eat it.   I love chips so when I need that crunch I will try to eat healthier versions, sweet potato chips,  vegetable chips, baked corn tortillas ( I have to be careful not to eat too many). I love all food.  So when there is something served with pasta or rice I try to control the portion size of the "white  stuff"and use veggies as my filler, often fresh baby spinach. Diet Coke is something I try to limit cause I tend to over indulge. Iced tea is my usual drink though water  should be. I have had birthday cake a few times and when I take my G'son to the movies I can't resist a treat but I go for quality, like dark chocolate.  In the past 14 weeks I have lost over 16 pounds eating like this AND I have been on vacation several weeks of this time. I think I can live with this approach for the rest of my life.  I have lost over 32 pounds since last October.  The first 16 was lost eating Vegan before 6.  It worked but was too restrictive for someone that likes to eat lunch out daily with her husband. I also discovered that too much soy makes my joints hurt.  Another thing that has helped me stay  on track has been an app my friend Jamie Keith recommended,  myfitnesspal.  After doing WW for years, I was not too hip on writing everything I eat,  but this approach is very painless.  I am friends with Jamie and we can see each other's successes and cheer each other on.  It has more bells and whistles than I need but you can use it to fit your needs.  Over the past couple of years I have tried to add movement to my life.  It has been a slow process but I have to admit in recent months I have started to ramp up. I started out with walking with my friend and doing water aerobics with my sweetie. I have now taken the plunge and hired a personal trainer.  I think this will escalate my weight loss and strength.  I have to admit, I'm starting to enjoy moving.    I hope this is read by someone that need encouragement.  I'm always looking for buddies to walk with or play with that want to live feeling good.  Let's hook up !

When protein is consumed, the body breaks it down into amino acids, the building blocks of all proteins. Some of the amino acids from proteins are designated nonessential. This means they do not have to come from the diet because they can be synthesized by the body from other amino acids. Other amino acids  are considered essential, meaning that the body cannot synthesize them, and therefore must obtain them from the diet. Whenever the body makes a protein - when it builds muscle, for instance - it needs a variety of amino acids for the protein-making process. These amino acids may come from dietary protein or from the body’s own pool of amino acids.  Dietary proteins are considered to belong to two different groups, depending on the amino acids they provide. Complete proteins: Complete proteins contain ample amounts of all the essential amino acids. They are found in meat, fish, poultry, cheese, eggs, and milk. Note: All soybean products, such as tofu and soymilk, are complete proteins. Incomplete proteins:Incomplete proteins contain only some of the essential amino acids. These proteins are found in a variety of foods, including grains, legumes, and leafy green vegetables. To make a complete protein, combine beans with any one of the following: brown rice corn nuts seeds wheat OR combine brown rice with any one of the following: beans nuts seeds You want to make sure to get 50 - 60 grams of protein a day. To make sure that you are getting enough variety of amino acids in your diet, add protein-rich foods to meals and snacks as often as possible. Note: A combination of any grains, any nuts and seeds, any legumes (such as beans, peanuts, and peas), and a variety of mixed vegetables will make a complete protein.  Nutritional Healing - Phyllis A. Balch, CNC

To lose one pound of body weight in a week, a person must consume about 500 fewer calories than he or she burns each day. Here are 18 ways to lose weight without going on a diet.1. Instead of drinking orange juice at breakfast, eat a whole orange. You’ll save about 45 calories.2. Make your breakfast omelette with four egg whites plus 1/4 cup egg substitute. Replace regular bacon with Canadian bacon to save even more calories.3. Switch from whole milk to nonfat or lowfat milk. Use sugar substitute instead of sugar in your morning coffee or latte.4. At lunch, use mustard instead of mayonnaise on your sandwich to save 100 calories (per tablespoon) . Eliminate the cheese and save 100 more calories.5. Instead of a Big Mac and large fries, go for a plain hamburger and a small french fry and save a whopping 590 calories!6. Don’t eat potato chips at snack time. Have an apple instead for less calories plus the added benefit of more fiber.7. Substitute diet cola or iced tea for your usual soda. You’ll save 150-200 calories per drink.8. Eat every two to three hours with smaller portions. Don’t skip breakfast! Eating small, frequent meals keeps blood glucose levels stable and minimizes the impulse to overeat.9. Eat more healthy snacks like dried fruits and nuts, fresh fruits, cut up veggies or yogurt.10. Substitute whole grain foods for white bread, rice and cereals. You will not only cut fat and calories, but whole grains have been proven to reduce the risk of colon cancer by increasing the fiber that your body needs.11. Saute meat, chicken and vegetables in broth instead of butter. And speaking of butter: replace it with nonfat sour cream on baked potatoes.12. Instead of Caesar salad, substitute a dinner sald with nonfat salad dressing.13. Do you love pasta? Have spaghetti with marinara sauce instead of fettuccini with Alfredo sauce. You’ll save at least 500 calories!14. When you’re going out with friends, watch your alcohol intake. Instead of using Coke or Seven-Up with your drinks, choose tonic water or seltzer.15. Restaurants are notorious for their huge serving sizes. Eat only half of your dinner and save the rest for lunch tomorrow. Or simply share the meal with a friend.16. Get moving. Walk to the store instead of driving. Walking is the best exercise you can do to lose weight.17. Get more walking time by replacing coffee breaks with exercise breaks. Also use half of your lunch break to take a brisk walk with a co-worker.18. Swim, swim, swim. By swimming for just an hour you can burn 500 calories. You’ll also end up with a firmer, more toned body.You don’t have to go on a strict diet to lose weight. Change to more sensible eating habits and start moving your body by walking, swimming or bicycle riding. You’ll be rewarded by good health and a fit body.
